events.originalText: Three days before her seventeenth birthday, Jessica Watson arrived in Sydney after sailing non-stop and unassisted around the world.
events.subtitle: Jessica Watson
events.headline: Jessica Watson completes solo non-stop sail around the world, arrives in Sydney

events.originalText: Arsenal became the first football team in England's top flight to finish a season undefeated since Preston North End did so in 1888–1889.
events.subtitle: Arsenal F.C.
events.headline: Arsenal finishes season undefeated, first team since Preston North End in 1888-1889

events.originalText: Vincent van Gogh's Portrait of Dr. Gachet was sold at auction at Christie's in New York for US$82.5 million, making it the world's most expensive painting at the time.
events.subtitle: Vincent van Gogh
events.headline: Van Gogh's Portrait of Dr. Gachet sold for US$82.5 million at Christie's auction

events.originalText: The Ryukyu Islands were returned to Japan by the United States, and the U.S. occupation government was abolished.
events.subtitle: Ryukyu Islands
events.headline: Ryukyu Islands returned to Japan by United States, occupation government abolished

events.originalText: Police opened fire during a confrontation with a group of Jackson State College students, killing two students and injuring twelve others.
events.subtitle: Jackson State killings
events.headline: Police open fire on Jackson State College students, killing two and injuring twelve

events.originalText: Disapproving of General Tôn Thất Đính's handling of the Buddhist Uprising, South Vietnamese prime minister Nguyễn Cao Kỳ ordered an attack on his forces and ousted Đính from his post.
events.subtitle: Tôn Thất Đính
events.headline: South Vietnamese prime minister orders attack on General Tôn Thất Đính's forces

events.originalText: The United Kingdom tested its first hydrogen bomb over Malden Island in Operation Grapple.
events.subtitle: Thermonuclear weapon
events.headline: United Kingdom tests first hydrogen bomb over Malden Island in Operation Grapple

events.originalText: Don Murphy organized the first pinewood derby, an event for Cub Scouts of the Boy Scouts of America where wooden cars built by the scouts are raced.
events.subtitle: Pinewood derby
events.headline: First pinewood derby organized by Don Murphy for Cub Scouts of Boy Scouts of America

events.originalText: The British Army directed fleeing Croatian soldiers to surrender to the Yugoslav Partisans, beginning the Bleiburg repatriations.
events.subtitle: British Army
events.headline: British Army directs fleeing Croatian soldiers to surrender to Yugoslav Partisans

events.originalText: Jesse Washington, a teenage African-American farmhand, was lynched in Waco, Texas.
events.subtitle: Lynching of Jesse Washington
events.headline: African-American farmhand Jesse Washington lynched in Waco, Texas

events.originalText: Mexican Revolution: A force of Maderistas captured Torreón and proceeded to massacre 303 of the city's Chinese residents.
events.subtitle: Mexican Revolution
events.headline: Maderistas capture Torreón, massacre 303 Chinese residents during Mexican Revolution

events.originalText: Russo-Japanese War: The Japanese battleships Hatsuse and Yashima sank after striking several mines off Port Arthur, China.
events.subtitle: Russo-Japanese War
events.headline: Japanese battleships Hatsuse and Yashima sink off Port Arthur in Russo-Japanese War

events.originalText: Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton founded the National Woman Suffrage Association, breaking away from the American Equal Rights Association which they had also previously founded.
events.subtitle: Susan B. Anthony
events.headline: Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton found National Woman Suffrage Association

events.originalText: American Civil War: A small Confederate force, which included cadets from the Virginia Military Institute, forced the Union Army out of the Shenandoah Valley.
events.subtitle: American Civil War
events.headline: Confederate force, including VMI cadets, forces Union Army out of Shenandoah Valley

events.originalText: Thieves stole 224 pounds (102 kg) of gold from a train travelling from London to Folkestone, England.
events.subtitle: Great Gold Robbery
events.headline: 224 pounds of gold stolen from train travelling from London to Folkestone

events.originalText: English astronomer Francis Baily observed Baily's beads (example pictured), a phenomenon during a solar eclipse in which the rugged topography of the lunar limb allows sunlight to shine through.
events.subtitle: Francis Baily
events.headline: Francis Baily observes Baily's beads during solar eclipse

events.originalText: Early English explorer Bartholomew Gosnold arrived on Cape Cod in present-day Massachusetts.
events.subtitle: Bartholomew Gosnold
events.headline: Bartholomew Gosnold arrives on Cape Cod in present-day Massachusetts

events.originalText: Pope Innocent IV issued the papal bull Ad extirpanda, authorizing the use of torture on heretics during the Medieval Inquisition.
events.subtitle: Pope Innocent IV
events.headline: Pope Innocent IV authorizes use of torture on heretics with papal bull Ad extirpanda

events.originalText: Roman emperor Valentinian II (pictured) was found hanged in his residence in Vienne, in present-day France.
events.subtitle: Valentinian II
events.headline: Roman emperor Valentinian II found hanged in residence in Vienne, France
